page.title: 09FARMING IN THE HOLME VALLEY
page.content: The farming in the Holme Valley has been very much determined by its reief and{climate.}Valley slopes do not lend themselves to ploughing and cultivation. An annual precipitation of around 900mm for Huddersfield (more for the head of the valley and the surrounding moors) & mean temperature ranges of 3 to 16 degrees celcius also severely restrict arable farming. However, the West Yorks. conurbation to the north provided a ready local market for milk and{dairy farming} therefore developed in the valley. On the moors the rough grazing, unsuitable for cattle, was used for {sheep.}The breeds are those kept for their{wool}and this, together with other geographical factors, led to the growth of the important local wool textile industry (see page 11).
